info.name: Garden Grove
info.attribution:
Initial mod design, layout, maps, and tile designs by lm_3 using Microsoft Copilot and Paint.Net. Released to public domain under CC0.
Additional scripting, modification, and How to Play section done by DexDouglas, with assistance by LawDawg, and released to public domain under CC0.
Library image created using Copilot with prompt: "create a square image, aquarelle style, of a flower garden with bluebells, sunflowers, rosebushes and lilacs" and released to public domain under CC0.
info.description: Welcome to Garden Grove! You are competing to own the most beautiful garden-scapes among your opponents. Grow and claim gardens, expand adjacent to pergolas, and get bonuses for treasures you reach along the way.  First to run out of claim tokens, wins!
info.ruleText:
Setup:

Click to sit at any seat. Select one of the 4 maps available to play: Bluebell, Sunflower, Rosebush, and Lilac. All 4 maps have unique features that will be explained below but the basic rules are listed first.


After selecting a map and hitting "New Game" all active players will be dealt a hand of 3 tiles from the O-X tiles which have 2 different colors and also receive 5 O-O tiles in their private holders, which have 1 color. The tiles in your hand are visible to you, the tiles in your private O-O holders are hidden from you until you draw them in your hand. You can see what types of tiles your opponents have (O-X or O-O) which will help you make decisions throughout the game.



Deck composition:

There are 54 tiles in the O-X deck which consist of 18 tiles each of Red-Blue, Red-Green, and Green-Blue. There are 27 tiles in the O-O deck which consist of 9 tiles each of Red-Red, Blue-Blue, and Green-Green.


Your Turn:

On your turn, you will play one of the three tiles from your hand and then draw a replacement tile by clicking either the O-X or O-O "Draw" button near your name (Note: If you click the End Turn, you will automatically fill your hand with O-X tiles). When placing the tile, you can click it to rotate and you are allowed to place it anywhere on the board as long as it is orthogonally adjacent to another tile, or adjacent to one of the three starting spaces on the board. The colors do not have to match when placing a tile. You cannot cover the solid spaces on the board (pergolas, pots, and starting spaces). 


If you have created an area (garden) of 2 or more squares of the same color, and no one has claimed it, you must take one of your claim tokens and place it in this area. If your area becomes 5 squares or more, you can place a second claim token as your garden has become a "Great Garden".

A Great Garden can continue to grow, but no more claim tokens will be added to it. 


Taking over Gardens:

An opponent's garden can be taken over if a larger garden of the same color connects to it. One garden must be larger (more squares) than the other garden BEFORE the adjoining tile is placed. It is not allowed to place a tile if it would connect two gardens of the same size and color (unless they are your own gardens). When the larger garden touches the smaller garden of the same color, it will absorb the smaller garden. The claim token on the smaller garden is returned to that player and if it wasn't already a Great Garden, it will now become a Great Garden, and get a second claim token placed on it. If two gardens are Great Gardens, and the same color, they can never be joined.


Pergolas (shaded octagon spaces)

If you own a garden and it touches a side of a pergola, and your garden is the first to touch it, you must place a claim token on the pergola. If another player's garden touches the pergola and has more claim tokens touching the pergola than you, then your claim token is returned to your supply and that player will place one of their claim tokens on the pergola.


Treasure spaces (diagonal O-O spaces)

If your tile is placed so that it covers one of the diagonal O-O spaces on the board, this permits you to click that O-O token on the board and draw a new O-O tile from the public O-O stack instead of your private stack. If this causes you to have 3 tiles in hand, you will not draw any additional tiles and simply end your turn when complete. Note that you do not need to have a claim token covering this space, you merely need to have placed a tile that covers the space.


End of Game

As soon as one player has placed all their claim tokens (24 in a 2 player game, 19 in a three player game, and 15 in a 4 player game), the game immediately ends and that person wins. If the draw stack ever runs out, continue playing tiles from your hand and if no one has won by the time all tiles have been played, the player who has placed the most claim tokens wins. 


Different Maps

The following will explain the unique features of the 4 different maps available to play. They are somewhat arranged in order of complexity with the easiest at the top (Bluebell) and the more complex at the bottom (Lilac). 


Bluebell:

Bluebell has pergolas that are 2 squares large. They are “Perfect Pergolas” and when you control them (per the Pergola rules), you can place TWO claim tokens on them instead of one. 


Sunflower:

Sunflower has Pot spaces. If you have a garden area with a claim token on it, and it is the first time that claim token has touched the pot, you will immediately take an additional action of placing a tile but you DO NOT draw another tile during this bonus placement. This means that with your bonus placement, you will only have 2 tiles in hand. If you place another claim token that touches a pot which would trigger another turn, it is forfeit. You may only have 1 bonus placement per turn. You, and your opponents, may touch the pot with multiple claimed garden areas from all 4 sides but only claimed garden areas that have NOT touched the pot before will trigger an extra turn. If your opponent has placed a garden that triggered a free action, and then on a later turn, you absorb that garden with a claimed garden of your own that had not touched that same pot, then you would trigger a bonus action. At the end of your turn, you draw up to 3 as normal, choosing which piles to draw from, one at a time. 


Rosebush:

Rosebush has pergola spaces with 1 or 2 circles within them. The pergolas with a single circle are just normal pergolas, but the pergolas with 2 circles are “Pavilions”. Pavilions can only be claimed when you have at least two of your claim tokens touching them. This can be with a single “Great Garden” or two smaller gardens.


Lilac:

Lilac has Perfect Pergolas (which allow placement of 2 claim tokens when controlling), pot spaces (which grant an extra turn when a claim token touches them), Pavilions (which require two claim tokens to claim), and Urn spaces. Urn spaces are similar to Pot spaces in that they grant you an extra tile placement, but in order to activate them you have to cover them the same way you cover treasure spaces. You do not need to have a claim token on, or touching, the Urn spaces to trigger the extra placement. Remember, you can only have two placements a turn, regardless of what you cover or touch. 


VARIANTS:

Series

If you want a series of games, decide on a number of games, or maps, to play in advance and keep track of how many claim tokens you had left at the end of each game. The player with the lowest combined total at the end of the series is the overall winner. 


Team Mode 2v2:

Team mode is played with all the same rules as a normal 4 player game but partners sit in an AABB rotation. This means that each team will take two turns in succession, and then the other team will take two turns in succession. The first turn of the game will be by the second player of one of the teams. For example, the first 4 turns of a game would go, Team B, Team A, Team A, then Team B, and repeat. Each player of the team will have their own set of 15 claim tokens, their own stack of 5 private O-O tiles, and their own private hand of 3 tiles. A player can play tiles to expand their partners gardens, even absorbing their own gardens if they like, but any pot activations that occur on turns for the non-active player are ignored.


The game ends whenever one player runs out of claim tokens, at that point, you tally which team has the least # of combined claim tokens, and they are the winners. In the event of a tie, the team that had the player who played all their claim tokens first, are the winners.


Teammates may not share or disclose what tiles they have in hand. The first player of the team must make their move completely independent of the second player of the team. Only after the first player makes their move, can they communicate their intention or wishes to the second player as they confer. 

If you’d prefer to have no communication at all, you can choose to play this way as well.
